user_request: A poem where the speaker compares a lover to a summer day but concludes the beloved outlasts it.

revision_history.draft:
She pressed her mouth to the crook
of my neck and I felt
the air leave me
like a monitor's line
going flat.

The sheets were cool.
The sheets were also warm.
I could not tell which
was real. Her hand
on my stomach, pushing down,
pushing into the thing
that keeps on ticking

even when you think
you've passed the point
of no return. Air conditioner
humming its small
lullaby. A hall somewhere
downstairs somebody crying
a name that sounds like mine.

I wanted to stay here.
I still want it.
The body doesn't mind
the fever. The body
is the fever now—
Radiator buzzing
under the sheet, both of us
breathing thick enough
to fog a window
and refusing

to wipe it clean.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The opening three lines — "She pressed her mouth to the crook / of my neck and I felt / the air leave me" — have genuine physical force. The verb *pressed* is precise, and *I felt the air leave me* lands with a real medical clarity that earns its place in this poem's domain (hospital room, monitor). That line also sets up a structure where sheets and monitors and breath become indistinguishable without forcing rhyme or easy repetition.

The radiator passage from lines 25–30 is the strongest sustained sequence. "Both of us breathing thick enough / to fog a window" — that's concrete, sensory, and earns its metaphor because it stays in the physical world (fogging glass) rather than floating away into fever-logic. The closing image of refusal to wipe clean has genuine emotional weight.

The fragmentation direction is working. Lines average 5–6 words apiece with real variation, and minimal punctuation lets the line breaks do structural work — "I could not tell which / was real" uses that break as a hinge between sheets-as-cool-sheets-and-warm-things-blurring.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Rhyme intrusion (lines 4, 10, 19):** The poem's form guidance specifically bans rhyme and then allows "line" / "down" (pyrrhic trochee) in line 10 and "line" / "mine" (perfect rhyme by accident) in line 19. These need to go or the form brief needs revision — right now it reads as contradictory.

**"The thing that keeps on ticking" (line 12):** This is a cliché dressed in vagueness. It tells us about a pulse monitor without any of the specificity that made "monitor's line going flat" work so well earlier. Direction: replace with language that stays inside the hospital equipment, not the generic poem-of-intimacy.

**"A hall somewhere / downstairs somebody crying
a name that sounds like mine." (lines 16–18):** This is pure atmosphere padding. It doesn't earn its place — it's a sound heard from offstage in a way that adds nothing to the intimacy or fever-logic the poem has been building. Direction: cut entirely, or find a detail as specific as "monitor's line going flat."

**"The body doesn't mind
the fever." (lines 24–25):** This is the one place where the poem abandons its own language for a thesis statement. It explains rather than enacts. Direction: replace with image or action — let the fever be *in* the body, not commented on.

**"Radiator buzzing
under the sheet." (line 27):** "Buzzing" is doing too much work as a rhyme word and

revision_history.draft:
She pressed her mouth to the crook
of my neck and I felt
the air leave me
like a monitor's line
going flat.

The sheets were cool. The sheets were also warm.
I could not tell which
was real. Her hand
on my stomach, pushing down,
pushing into the tube
that threads through the diaphragm
into the space where breath
is made.

A hall somewhere downstairs somebody crying
a name that doesn't reach us—just
the hum of a ventilator
somewhere inside the building's lungs,

her thumb against my costal margin,
measuring where the lung
pulls in its quiet way.
The radiator vibrates metal
through the sheet, heat
thick enough to fog
a window and refusing

to be wiped clean.

Bolus of sugar sliding down the tract
that doesn't mind. The body
enveloped in its own fever—
tongue heavy in the mouth,
skin a read so deep it looks
like something lanced,

and I am not reaching for the wipe
but neither am I staying still.
The window fogged with our breathing
holds a specific opacity:
we will not clear it. We will

keep being warm
in the way that only patients learn—
the heat of being kept,
the sweated sheet, the towel
someone forgets to bring,

and in the morning the mattress
will read us both as wet
as something left out past its hour.
The ventilator never stops its small
lullaby. The monitor
holds its green constancy.

I could describe her hand
but I will not—describe the thing
that holds you down is to make it
ordinary, and it isn't ordinary—

it is the weight of glass
lowering over a flat screen,
the beep that comes from air forced into tubing,
and me, inside its sound,
inside its light.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The radiator passage (lines 25–30) is the strongest sustained sequence in the draft. "Both of us breathing thick enough / to fog a window" — that's concrete, sensory, and earns its metaphor because it stays in the physical world (fogging glass) rather than floating away into fever-logic. The closing image of refusal to wipe clean has genuine emotional weight.

The opening three lines ("She pressed her mouth to the crook / of my neck and I felt / the air leave me") land with real force — "air leave me" is precise medical language that earns its place in this poem's domain (hospital room, monitor). That line also sets up a structure where sheets and monitors and breath become indistinguishable without forcing rhyme or easy repetition.

The fragmentation direction is working. Lines average 5–6 words apiece with real variation, and minimal punctuation lets the line breaks do structural work — "I could not tell which / was real" uses that break as a hinge between sheets-as-cool-sheets-and-warm-things-blurring.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Rhyme intrusion (lines 4, 10, 19):**
- **Line 4:** "line" / "felt" — slant rhyme, but the word is doing other work ("monitor's line going flat"). Direction: replace with a synonym or find a different phrase that doesn't need to rhyme.
- **Line 10:** "which" / "flat" — no rhyme pair. Direction: rewrite so the line doesn't need this filler word.
- **Line 19:** "line" / "down" — slant, but also accidental perfect rhyme with "thing." Direction: cut or replace.

**Abstraction and explanation (lines 24–25):**
- **"The body doesn't mind / the fever."** This is a thesis statement where the poem should be enacting. Direction: replace with image — let the fever *be* in the body, not commented on.

**Cliché or vague language (line 18):**
- **"a name that sounds like mine."** Pure atmosphere padding. Direction: cut entirely, or find a detail as specific as "monitor's line going flat."

**Thinning of imagery domain:**
The draft drifts into domestic and generic hospital furniture — sheets, radiator, vent, window, monitor — but doesn't stay inside the specialized equipment the brief demands (air conditioners, pulse monitors on glass). Direction: audit every image. If it could appear in any poem about intimacy, it's not specific enough for this one.

**Line 12:**
- **"the thing that keeps on ticking"** — cliché dressed in vagueness. Direction: replace with language that stays inside the pulse monitor or ventilator.

She pressed her mouth to the crook
of my neck and I felt
the air leave me
like a monitor's line
going flat.

The sheets were cool. The sheets were also warm.
I could not tell which was real. Her hand
on my stomach, pushing down,
pushing into the tube
that threads through diaphragm
into where breath is made.

A hall somewhere downstairs somebody crying
a name that doesn't reach us—just
the hum of a ventilator
somewhere inside the building's lungs,

her thumb against my costal margin,
measuring where the lung
pulls in its quiet way.
The radiator vibrates metal
through the sheet, heat
thick enough to fog
a window and refusing

to be wiped clean.

Bolus of sugar sliding down the tract
that doesn't mind. The body
enveloped in its own fever—
tongue heavy in the mouth,
skin a read so deep it looks
like something lanced,

and I am not reaching for the wipe
but neither am I staying still.
The window fogged with our breathing
holds a specific opacity:
we will not clear it. We will

keep being warm
in the way that only patients learn—
the heat of being kept,
the sweated sheet, the towel
someone forgets to bring,

and in morning the mattress
will read us both as wet
as something left out past its hour.
The ventilator never stops its small
lullaby. The pulse monitor
holds its green constancy.

I could describe her hand
but I will not—describe the thing
that holds you down is to make it
ordinary, and it isn't ordinary—

it is the weight of glass
lowering over a flat screen,
the beep that comes from air forced into tubing,
and me, inside its sound,
inside its light.

like something lanced,

revision_history.draft:
She pressed her mouth to the crook
of my neck and I felt
the air leave me,
like a monitor's line
going flat.

The sheets were fogged. The radiator
vibrated its thin metal through them.
I could not tell which was real—

her hand on my stomach, pushing down,
pushing into the soft country
where breath is made.

A hall downstairs somebody crying
a name that sounds like mine—just
the hum of a ventilator
somewhere inside the building's belly,

her thumb against my ribcage,
measuring where the lung
pulls in its quiet way.
The sheet crinkling, white-warmed,
and I am not reaching for the wipe
but neither am I staying still.

Our breathing fogged the window
into a specific opacity:
we will not clear it. We will

keep being warm
in the way that only patients learn—
the heat of being kept,
the wet sheet, the towel
someone forgets to bring,

and in morning the mattress
will read us both as damp
as something left out past its hour.
The ventilator never stops its small
lullaby. The pulse monitor
holds its green constancy.

I could describe her hand
but I will not—describe the thing
that holds you down is to make it
ordinary, and it isn't ordinary—

it is the weight of glass
lowering over a flat screen,
the beep that comes from air forced into tubing,

and me, inside its sound,
inside its light.

revision_history.draft:
She pressed her mouth to the crook
of my neck and I felt
the air leave me,
like a glass syringe
drawing blood from stillness.

The sheets were fogged. The radiator
vibrated its thin metal through them.
I could not tell which was real—

her hand on my stomach, pushing down,
pushing into the soft country
where breath is made.

A hall downstairs somebody crying
a name that sounds like mine—just
the hum of a ventilator
somewhere inside the building's belly,

her thumb against my ribcage,
measuring where the lung
pulls in its quiet way.
The sheet crinkling, white-warmed,
and I am not reaching for the wipe
but neither am I staying still.

Our breathing fogged the window
into a specific opacity:
we will not clear it. We will

keep being warm
in the way that only patients learn—
the heat of being kept,
the wet sheet, the towel
someone forgets to bring,

and in morning the mattress
will read us both as damp
as something left out past its hour.
The ventilator never stops its small
lullaby. The pulse monitor
holds its green constancy.

I could describe her hand
but I will not—describe the thing
that holds you down is to make it
ordinary, and it isn't ordinary—

it is the weight of glass
lowering over a flat screen,
the beep that comes from air forced into tubing,

and me, inside its sound,
inside its light.

of my neck and I felt
the air leave me,
like a glass syringe
drawing blood from stillness.

The sheets were fogged. The radiator
vibrated its thin metal through them.
